pullRequest.body:
This PR adds the functoriality of the Grothendieck construction by providing 
```
map (α : F ⟶ G) : Grothendieck F ⥤ Grothendieck G
```
and then promotes the Grothendieck construction into a functor from the functor category
`C ⥤ Cat` to the over category `Over C` in the category of categories:

```
def functor {E : Cat.{v,u}} : (E ⥤ Cat.{v,u}) ⥤ Over (T:= Cat.{v,u}) E
```

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [d3333691c0](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14387/commits/d3333691c067dbe9a395732ac600ac7ba5b62cbb)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Grothendieck | 400 | 401 | +1 (+0.25%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Grothendieck`|1|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ comp_fiber'`
`+ functor`
`+ functor_comp_forget`
`+ map`
`+ mapCompIso`
`+ mapIdIso`
`+ map_comp_eq`
`+ map_id_eq`
`+ map_map`
`+ map_obj`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

</details>

In case you are interested, I have the grothendieck construction in terms of pseudofunctors on the branch [fiberedcategories_pseudofunctor](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/fiberedcategories_pseudofunctor) (and I also show its a fibered category). It will take a while to get PRd though, as it depends on a bunch of open fibered category PRs, and I also need to add some API around pseudofunctors.

> In case you are interested, I have the grothendieck construction in terms of pseudofunctors on the branch [fiberedcategories_pseudofunctor](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/fiberedcategories_pseudofunctor) (and I also show its a fibered category). It will take a while to get PRd though, as it depends on a bunch of open fibered category PRs, and I also need to add some API around pseudofunctors.

That is interesting to know! However, for another project, I need the strict functoriality of Grothendieck construction for functors.  Sure, it'd be great to have pseudo-functoriality as well, but that will be a separate case I think, since that will be a statement about 2-functors. The current Grothendieck construction is about 1-functors to `Cat` and this is the version I need for my project.

> > In case you are interested, I have the grothendieck construction in terms of pseudofunctors on the branch [fiberedcategories_pseudofunctor](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/tree/fiberedcategories_pseudofunctor) (and I also show its a fibered category). It will take a while to get PRd though, as it depends on a bunch of open fibered category PRs, and I also need to add some API around pseudofunctors.
> 
> That is interesting to know! However, for another project, I need the strict functoriality of Grothendieck construction for functors. Sure, it'd be great to have pseudo-functoriality as well, but that will be a separate case I think, since that will be a statement about 2-functors. The current Grothendieck construction is about 1-functors to `Cat` and this is the version I need for my project.

Okay good! Just wanted to make sure that we didn't overlap/redo work, since we have been working on somewhat similar things!

Still not the fastest proof but totally fine, thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10019987336/job/27697147892)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10019987336/job/27697148067)
LGTM.
Other than the slowness in `map`, this looks good to me.
Found a slightly faster proof

```suggestion
  obj X := {
    base := X.base
    fiber := (α.app X.base).obj X.fiber }
  map {X Y} f := {
    base := f.base
    fiber := (eqToHom (α.naturality f.base).symm).app X.fiber ≫ (α.app Y.base).map f.fiber }
  map_id X := by
    simp only [Cat.comp_obj, id_fiber', eqToHom_map]
    congr 1
    rw [eqToHom_app, eqToHom_trans]
  map_comp {X Y Z} f g := by
    dsimp
    congr 1
    erw [comp_fiber f g]
    simp only [← Category.assoc, Functor.map_comp, eqToHom_map]
    apply congrFun (congrArg (. ≫ .) ?_) ((α.app Z.base).map g.fiber)
    have H := Functor.congr_hom (α.naturality g.base).symm f.fiber
    erw [H, eqToHom_app, eqToHom_app]
    simp only [Cat.comp_obj, eqToHom_trans, eqToHom_map, Cat.comp_map, eqToHom_trans_assoc,
      Category.assoc]
    erw [eqToHom_app]
    simp
```
This `erw` suggests that there is a simp lemma missing. Maybe you can add a new version of `comp_fiber` after the `Category` instance phrased in terms of `≫` instead of `comp`?
sounds a good idea!
just added a new lemma `comp_fiber'` similar to already existing `id_fiber'` and now we use `simp [comp_fiber' f g]` instead of `erw [comp_fiber f g]`.

```suggestion
    simp [NatTrans.id_app]
```

```suggestion
def functor {E : Cat.{v,u}} : (E ⥤ Cat.{v,u}) ⥤ Over (T := Cat.{v,u}) E where
  obj F := Over.mk (X := E) (Y := Cat.of (Grothendieck F)) (Grothendieck.forget F)
```

```suggestion
  map_comp α β := by
    simp [Grothendieck.map_comp_eq α β]
    rfl
```
Would `map_id_eq` be a bad simp lemma? If it were a simp lemma then automation would take care of this (simliar for `map_comp_eq`)
`map_id_eq` and `map_comp_eq` are equalities of functors. I thought we are discouraged from writing `@simp` lemmas for equalities of functors due to their bad rewriting behavior.

See for instance in the comment just above [docs#CategoryTheory.Functor.comp_id](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/dff9f5d732525aed55b9ec6b8cfcc148f35be07b/Mathlib/CategoryTheory/Functor/Basic.lean#L129-L129).
I see, probably best not to make them simp lemmas then

```suggestion
def mapIdIso : map (𝟙 F) ≅ 𝟙 (Cat.of <| Grothendieck <| F) := eqToIso map_id_eq
```
@dagurtomas: Actually, changing `erw` to `simp` breaks the proof.
Is there a way to fix it?
It seems `rw [NatTrans.id_app]; simp` also works, but `simp [NatTrans.id_app]` does not.
Ok, `rw` is better than `erw`, but I don't know why `simp` doesn't just close the goal
yeah, I could not make it work with any of the  `simp` or `simp only` or `simp [-x, y, ...]`. I don't understand what is going on.
It seems `simp [NatTrans.id_app]` does not work! we can do `rw[NatTrans.id_app]; simp` if that is better?

```suggestion
  obj X :=
  { base := X.base
    fiber := (α.app X.base).obj X.fiber }
```

```suggestion
  map {X Y} f :=
  { base := f.base
    fiber := (eqToHom (α.naturality f.base).symm).app X.fiber ≫ (α.app Y.base).map f.fiber }
```

Missed these non-terminal simps. please squeeze them.
(there are more elsewhere)
replaces `simp` proofs by `simp only [...]` and minimized the arguments of `simp only`.

```suggestion
    Grothendieck.map α ⋙ Grothendieck.forget G = Grothendieck.forget F := rfl
```

```suggestion
    ⟨f.base, (eqToHom (α.naturality f.base).symm).app X.fiber ≫ (α.app Y.base).map f.fiber⟩ := rfl
```

```suggestion
    (Grothendieck.map α).obj X = ⟨X.base, (α.app X.base).obj X.fiber⟩ := rfl
```
This `def` seems very slow, can you try to make it faster? Thanks!
I agree this is a bit slow, it might help to split it up into separate defs `mapObj` and `mapMap`, and lemmas `map_map_id` and `map_map_comp`.
It's only the `map_comp` field that's slow, it seems

```suggestion
    apply congrFun (congrArg (· ≫ ·) ?_) ((α.app Z.base).map g.fiber)
    have H := Functor.congr_hom (α.naturality g.base).symm f.fiber
```
It's this `erw` that's making the proof slow. Maybe there are some `simp` lemmas missing?

```suggestion
    dsimp
    congr 1
    simp only [comp_fiber' f g, ← Category.assoc, Functor.map_comp, eqToHom_map]
    congr 1
    simp only [Cat.comp_obj, eqToHom_trans, eqToHom_map, Cat.comp_map, eqToHom_trans_assoc,
      Category.assoc]
    rw [eqToHom_app, eqToHom_app, eqToHom_app]
    erw [Functor.congr_hom (α.naturality g.base).symm f.fiber]
    simp
```

This seems a bit faster
It's basically the same proof, just moving the slow `erw` further back

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - promoting the Grothendieck construction into a functor
